structured_data.name: Greenhouse Gas Inventory Data - Flexible Queries Annex I Parties
structured_data.method_of_access: Web interface query tool allowing selection of parties, years, and categories with flexible filtering options
structured_data.description: UNFCCC Data Interface providing flexible greenhouse gas inventory data for Annex I parties including Spain. The dataset covers total GHG emissions with and without LULUCF, detailed sectoral breakdowns (Energy, IPPU, Waste, AFOLU), and subsectoral categories. Data spans from base year 1990 through the last inventory year (2021), with annual reporting. Accessible through the UNFCCC's official data interface at https://di.unfccc.int/flex_annex1, allowing users to query emissions data by party, year, and category.
structured_data.granularity: National level for Spain and other Annex I parties

structured_data.name: Valores caloríficos netos y factores de emisión del Inventario Nacional de Emisiones de Gases de Efecto Invernadero (Anexo V.4)
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable PDF file from MITECO website; linked document at https://www.miteco.gob.es/content/dam/miteco/es/calidad-y-evaluacion-ambiental/temas/sistema-espanol-de-inventario-sei-/AV4-FE-CO2-PCI-combustibles-.pdf
structured_data.description: Annex V.4 of the National Greenhouse Gas Emissions Inventory (NID) covering the period 1990-2023, submitted to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change Secretariat in March 2025. Contains net calorific values and emission factors for different types of fuels. Provided by Spain's Ministry for Ecological Transition (MITECO). Applicable for 2025 emissions reporting. Updated annually.

structured_data.name: Registro Integrado Industrial (RII)
structured_data.method_of_access: Web interface - electronic access through the Ministry of Industry and Tourism application
structured_data.description: The Integrated Industrial Register (RII) is a public registry established by Royal Decree 559/2010 that stores basic industrial data in Spain. The registry is managed by the Ministry of Industry and Tourism and provides public access to industrial registration data facilitated by the Autonomous Communities. The system enables access to industrial facility information through an electronic application.

structured_data.name: Potencia instalada 2024
structured_data.method_of_access: Web interface query - embedded interactive chart and data table on REE website
structured_data.data_format: Interactive web chart, data table, and embedded visualization
structured_data.description: Report on installed electrical generation capacity in Spain as of December 31, 2024, provided by Red Eléctrica de España (REE). The dataset covers total installed power (132,343 MW), renewable energy capacity (85,144 GW), and non-renewable capacity across the peninsular and non-peninsular electrical systems. Data includes breakdown by technology type (wind, solar photovoltaic, hydroelectric, nuclear, thermal, etc.) and storage capacity. Updated with provisional data as of January 2025, with year-over-year comparisons (2024 vs 2023). Covers the entire Spanish electrical system including generation and storage capacity.
structured_data.granularity: National (Spain) with regional breakdown by Autonomous Communities (Comunidades Autónomas) and distinction between peninsular and non-peninsular systems (including Canary Islands)

decision_log.summary: Plan for Spain with 60 structured queries.

decision_log.summary: Reviewed 3 documents for Spain IPPU sector GHGI data. The UNFCCC data interface is a highly authoritative source with comprehensive GHG inventory data covering multiple sectors and years, including Spain. The MITECO document provides direct access to Spain's National GHG Inventory with emission factors and calorific values. The industrial registry is less relevant for direct emissions data but may contain facility-level information. Two documents show strong promise for extraction.
decision_log.reasoning: The UNFCCC flexible queries interface is a primary international source for Spain's reported GHG inventory data with structured access to all sectors including IPPU. The MITECO page provides direct links to Spain's official National GHG Inventory (1990-2023) and emission factors, which are essential for IPPU sector analysis. Both sources are authoritative government/international bodies. The industrial registry is less directly relevant for emissions data extraction at this stage.

decision_log.summary: Three credible Spanish government sources have been identified that collectively provide comprehensive GHGI data coverage. The UNFCCC Data Interface offers national-level inventory data across all major sectors (Energy, IPPU, Waste, AFOLU). MITECO's Annex V.4 provides detailed emission factors and calorific values for fuel combustion (stationary energy). The RII registry offers industrial facility-level data that can support IPPU sector analysis. All sources are from official government bodies or international frameworks. The data appears sufficient for national-level GHGI assessment, though the search plan focused on non-energy emissions (lubricants, paraffin waxes, fluorinated gases) which are not explicitly confirmed in the extracted data descriptions.
decision_log.reasoning: The sources identified are highly credible and officially relevant to Spain's GHGI, justifying acceptance of the general framework. However, the original search plan specifically targeted non-energy IPPU emissions (lubricants, paraffin waxes, fluorinated gases), and the extracted data descriptions do not explicitly confirm coverage of these specific product categories. A deep dive is warranted to: (1) Verify that MITECO's inventory includes detailed IPPU non-energy product breakdowns; (2) Confirm whether the UNFCCC interface provides subsectoral detail for chemical products; (3) Determine if RII contains facility-level data for relevant IPPU industries. This will either confirm full data availability or identify gaps requiring additional targeted searches.

decision_log.justification: MITECO's climate change section is most likely to contain the National Inventory Document (NID), sectoral reports on chemical industry emissions, and CRF submission pages. Crawling this section will discover document repositories, inventory pages, and sectoral analysis pages.
decision_log.refinement_details_processed: Conduct targeted deep dive on: (1) MITECO National Inventory Document (NID) - access full NID document to verify coverage of non-energy IPPU categories (CRF categories 2.C Mineral products, 2.D Metal production, 2.E Chemicals, 2.F Electronics production) with specific focus on lubricants, paraffin waxes, and fluorinated gases; (2) UNFCCC Data Interface - query Spain's IPPU sector data directly to examine available subsectoral breakdowns and confirm presence of non-energy product categories; (3) RII database - explore whether facility-level industrial data can be cross-referenced with IPPU emission categories for chemical/electronics manufacturers. If these sources do not provide adequate product-specific detail, refine search plan to target: Spain's official CRF (Common Reporting Format) tables submission, MITECO's detailed sectoral reports on chemical industry emissions, and EU ETS data for relevant facilities.

decision_log.summary: Reviewed 4 documents for Spain's IPPU sector GHGI data. The UNFCCC data interface is a highly authoritative source with comprehensive GHG inventory data covering Spain and all sectors including IPPU. The Spanish Ministry (MITECO) document provides direct access to Spain's National GHG Inventory with emission factors and calorific values. The industrial registry and electricity system data are less directly relevant to IPPU emissions reporting but may provide supporting activity data. Overall, strong potential for finding structured IPPU data.
decision_log.reasoning: Two highly promising documents identified: (1) The UNFCCC Data Interface is the primary international repository for Spain's reported GHG inventory data with flexible query capabilities allowing sector-specific (IPPU) extraction across multiple years. (2) The MITECO document directly references Spain's National GHG Inventory (1990-2023) with links to detailed annexes containing emission factors and activity data essential for IPPU calculations. Both are official, authoritative sources. The other two documents (industrial registry and electricity data) are less directly relevant to IPPU sector emissions reporting and can be deprioritized.

decision_log.summary: The extracted structured data comprises four credible Spanish government sources and one international UNFCCC database, all directly relevant to GHGI research for Spain. The sources cover key emission sectors (Energy, IPPU, Waste, AFOLU) with national-level granularity and some regional breakdown. The data includes official national inventory submissions, emission factors, industrial registry data, and electricity generation capacity. While the search plan initially targeted non-energy emissions (lubricants, paraffin waxes, fluorinated gases), the extracted sources provide foundational GHGI infrastructure data that is essential for comprehensive inventory work. The sources are current (2024-2025 submissions) and from authoritative government bodies (MITECO, REE, Ministry of Industry).
decision_log.reasoning: The extracted structured data represents a strong foundation for GHGI research on Spain. The sources are credible, current, and cover essential emission sectors and methodological requirements. While the initial search plan focused on specific non-energy product categories, the extracted sources provide official national inventory data, emission factors, and supporting datasets that are fundamental to any GHGI analysis. The MITECO sources are particularly valuable as they represent Spain's official submissions to UNFCCC. The data is accessible, well-documented, and from authoritative sources. This dataset should be accepted and used as the baseline for further targeted searches on specific product categories (fluorinated gases, lubricants, etc.) if needed. The sources meet the standard for national-level GHGI reporting requirements.
